intro: Solanum virginianum, commonly known as the eastern redcurrant, is a deciduous shrub native to eastern North America. It belongs to the nightshade family (Solanaceae) and is characterized by its clusters of small, red, edible berries. The plant typically grows to a height of 1–3 meters and has simple, alternate leaves with a slightly hairy surface. Its flowers are yellow with a white throat, and it thrives in moist, well-drained soils. The berries are often used in jams and preserves due to their tart flavor.
